Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 41539-01  
Regional–Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R–CDTA) 
February 2010 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Technical Training and Capacity Building for Selected 
Asian Countries on Regional Economic and Financial 
Monitoring 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  ASEAN+3  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations, plus People’s 
Republic of China, Japan, and Republic of Korea 
  CMIM  –  Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralization 
  EWS  –  early warning system 
  OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
  REFM  –  regional economic and financial monitoring 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—capacity development technical assistance (R–CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public  sector  management  (economic  and  public  affairs 
management)  
Theme (subtheme)  –  Regional  cooperation  and  integration  (money  and  finance), 
governance  (economic  and  financial  governance),  capacity 
development  (institutional  development),  economic  growth 
(promoting macroeconomic stability)

NOTE

Head  J. W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Senior Director  S. Madhur (OREI) 
   
Team leader  H. Y. Jeong, Economist, OREI 
Team member  J. Duque-Comia, Economics Officer, OREI 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In February 1998 in the wake of the 1997–1998 Asian financial crises, the finance 
ministers  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  met  in  Jakarta.  They 
discussed the concept of an ASEAN economic surveillance process. In an attempt to strengthen 
the capacity of national and regional institutions engaged in regional economic review and 
policy dialogue, they asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance 
(TA) to support the ASEAN surveillance process. ADB responded with a two-part capacity building 
effort: (i) support for establishment of national surveillance units in selected ASEAN countries, 
and (ii) provision of training on regional economic and financial monitoring for officers from 
finance  ministries  and  central  banks  of  selected  ASEAN+3  countries1  and  the  ASEAN 
Secretariat.  
2.  Since 1998, ADB has organized training programs that have evolved to the current 
course  on  regional  economic  and  financial  monitoring  (REFM).  Five  TAs  financed  these 
programs2  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  ASEAN+3  countries  in  economic  and  financial 
monitoring—299 mid-level government officials have completed REFM training. Many of these 
officials are now leading the design and implementation of national and regional surveillance in 
their respective countries and are actively involved in vulnerability assessment and economic 
policy formulation.  
3.  Given the remarkable performance and effectiveness of the training program, several 
ASEAN+3 countries and countries outside the region have asked ADB to support technical 
training on REFM. In particular, confronted by the unprecedented global financial crisis, several 
ADB member countries and international organizations have argued the need to provide more 
countries beyond ASEAN+3 with benefits of the surveillance-related training program. This is to 
strengthen the institutional and technical capacity of their officials for economic and financial 
monitoring,  and  build  capacity  to  formulate  effective  economic  policies  through  enhanced 
regional cooperation.3 This TA is designed to respond to these requests by bringing together 
the strengths identified in previous TAs. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The  ASEAN+3  Finance  Ministers'  Process  launched  several  initiatives  aimed  at 
enhancing domestic and regional economic and financial cooperation, which include the Chiang 
Mai  Initiative,  Asian  Bond  Markets  Initiative,  Economic  Review  and  Policy  Dialogue,  and 
                                                 
1  Brunei  Darussalam,  Cambodia,  People's  Republic  of  China,  Indonesia,  Lao  People's  Democratic  Republic, 
Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Republic of Korea, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
2  Previous TA projects include ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance for Technical Training and Capacity Building in 
Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process. Manila (TA 5827-REG); ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance 
for Technical Training and Capacity Building in Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process, Phase II. 
Manila (TA 6019-REG); Technical Assistance for Technical Training and Capacity Building in Support of the 
ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process, Phase III. Manila (TA 6071-REG); ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for 
Technical Training and Capacity Building in Support of the ASEAN Economic Surveillance Process, Phase IV. 
Manila  (TA  6201-REG);  and  ADB.  2006.  Technical  Training  and  Capacity  Building  for  Selected  ASEAN+3 
Countries on Regional Economic and Financial Monitoring. Manila (TA 6342-REG). 
3  In a meeting with Sri Lanka Central Bank officials during an ADB Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
seminar, OREI was asked to organize a training course on REFM for finance ministry and central bank officials of 
South Asian countries in collaboration with the Central Bank Centre for Banking Studies. Sri Lanka is the current 
chair of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation. 
4  The TA concept paper was approved on 15 October 2009. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities 
section of ADB's website on 19 November 2009.

2   
ASEAN+3 Research Group. In addition, a working group on economic and financial surveillance 
was created during the May 2006 meeting of the ASEAN+3 finance ministers in Hyderabad, 
India.  Staff  of  finance  ministries  and  central  banks  of  these  countries  are  involved  in  the 
initiatives. Continued support and strengthening of capacity development assistance for these 
officials on regional economic surveillance is essential to ensure success of activities initiated 
under the ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers' Process.  
 
5.  The TA takes into account agreements made during the ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers' 
Meeting in Bali in May 2009, on the establishment of the ASEAN+3 Macroeconomic Research 
Office. The office is an independent regional surveillance unit to monitor and analyze regional 
economies  and  to  support  decision  making  on  the  Chiang  Mai  Initiative  Multilateralization 
(CMIM)5. For the Macroeconomic Research Office to achieve its expected outcome, continuous 
efforts are needed to enhance the surveillance capacity of ASEAN+3 officials. The REFM 
training program is designed to support these capacity building efforts and this would, in the 
long term, lay the groundwork for stronger regional surveillance potential in relation to recent 
CMIM development. 
 
6.  While economic monitoring should adopt a multilateral perspective as well as country-
specific circumstances, surveillance needs to evolve with the changing environment of the 
global  economy.  For  instance,  the  recent  global  financial  crisis  showed  that  the  existing 
framework of financial regulation and supervision (i.e., the microprudential framework) tends to 
primarily  focus  on  the  stability  of  individual  institutions,  markets,  and  infrastructure,  while 
underestimating systemic risks. On the other hand, the macroprudential approach to supervision 
mainly focuses on the financial system as a whole and involves monitoring, assessment, and 
mitigation of systemic risk, namely the likelihood of failure of a significant part of the financial 
system.  In  this  context,  analytical  tools  for  integrating  financial  sector  and  capital  market 
analysis into macroeconomic assessments need to be developed to tackle financial sector 
issues arising from the recent global financial and economic meltdown, which is unmatched in 
the postwar era. 
 
7.  To address these issues, the TA incorporates two fundamental changes in terms of the 
geographic coverage of recipient countries and the focus of the training program. First, the scope 
of assistance will be expanded beyond ASEAN+3 to cover South Asian countries,6 which are 
increasingly vulnerable to changes in the external economic environment caused by incremental 
openness.  Second,  confronting  the  widespread  impact  of  the  unprecedented  financial  and 
economic shock, the TA will also address postcrisis surveillance issues ranging from capital 
liberalization, financial regulation, and macroprudential framework7—with a view to exploring 
their implications for the regional surveillance mechanism. 
                                                 
5  The CMIM is a reserve pooling arrangement that member economies could tap to help prevent a currency crisis. If 
an agreement on the CMIM is reached, a sound decision making process regarding the provision of funds (to 
affected countries) in a potential crisis will need to be put in place. 
6  Starting in 2010, in addition to the existing ASEAN+3 countries, the training program will invite selected developing 
member countries from South Asia. In this connection, during 14–18 Sep 2009, OREI provided 38 participants from 
eight South Asian countries with a short version of the REFM training workshop In Sri Lanka. The course was 
modeled on ADB's regular 4-week REFM course but adapted with a regional focus on South Asia as part of the 
response to requests by South Asian countries and the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
Secretariat for increased capacity-building on regional economic and financial monitoring in this region. The TA is a 
response to their request for a follow-up program with emphasis on more advanced vulnerability assessment tools. 
7  Macroprudential analysis is used in vulnerability assessment as a way to quantify and qualify the soundness and 
vulnerability of financial systems using macroeconomic data, financial soundness indicators, and information on the 
structure of the financial system and the institutional and regulatory framework (V. Sundararajan et al. 2002. 
Financial  Soundness  Indicators:  Analytical  Aspects  and  Country  Practices.  IMF  Occasional  Paper.  No.  22. 
Washington, DC: International Monetary Fund).

3   
 
 
8.  The number of participants per workshop will more than double from about 20 to about 40 
due to the expanded geographic coverage of the training course. The format of the program will 
be revised to improve the effectiveness of the course. Each subregion fundamentally faces a 
great diversity in terms of economic development, openness, trade, and financial market maturity. 
Thus, the lecture contents provided for participants and its program format will be customized to 
specific needs depending on subregional background. Lastly, the lack of high-frequency data in 
some countries is expected to make undertaking appropriate economic and statistical analyses 
required for surveillance work difficult. These issues need to be discussed with the participating 
countries to ensure that the benefits of the program are maximized. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA has four main objectives: (i) to build the capacity of officials from finance 
ministries  and  central  banks  of  developing  member  countries  in  economic  and  financial 
surveillance;  (ii)  to  provide  relevant  inputs  for  economic  policy-making  activities  through 
technical training programs and research; (iii) to prepare for the ASEAN+3 Macroeconomic 
Research Office’s expected role by promoting surveillance expertise built on shared principles 
and  techniques  across  the  region;  (iv)  to  modernize  national  surveillance  units  in  ASEAN 
countries  through  an  intensive  case  study  methodology  to  examine  their  unique  economic 
circumstances and explore their decade-long achievement and regional approach to economic 
surveillance. 
 
10.  The overall impact of the TA will be improved capacity for REFM surveillance and 
macroeconomic policy formulation for staff, up to mid-level officials, of finance ministries and 
central banks. In the long-run, this will lay the foundation for strengthened regional surveillance 
that  should  help  the  effective  management  of  the  CMIM.  In  addition,  the  TA  will  support 
establishment of an extensive alumni network with members that have identical principles and are 
knowledgeable in a wide range of topics such as economic and financial data systems, the early 
warning system (EWS) model, methods of economic policy analysis, and international standards 
in financial regulation and macroprudential frameworks. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The REFM technical course will involve about 100–120 mid-level staff from finance 
ministries and central banks through 3–4 batches of semiannual education programs. This is 
subject to the number of participating countries in the region and the venue for the training. The 
course  will  primarily  focus  on  financial  programming,  develop  capacity  to  assess  financial 
vulnerability, and conduct economic and financial analysis using EWS models. 
 
12.  The course will be divided into four parts. Part I will introduce the course and discuss 
surveillance  issues  in  the  context  of  the  theory  and  practice  of  regional  cooperation  and 
integration. Trainees will provide briefings on recent economic trends in their countries and 
recommend responses to them in terms of policy development. Part II will deal with issues 
related to macroeconomic financial programming and economic policies, with simulations of 
program scenarios. This will include a review of different macroeconomic and financial accounts, 
and formulation of macroeconomic polices. Part III will cover financial vulnerability assessments 
and leading indicators in detail. The experiences of a couple of countries with economic and 
financial surveillance will also be discussed, particularly in terms of its role and effectiveness in

4   
the midst of the recent global economic and financial crisis. Part IV will introduce and analyze 
EWS models, including the vulnerability indicators and early warning systems (VIEWS) model 
developed by ADB’s Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI). This part will also address 
selected timely topics related to regional cooperation and integration and economic surveillance, 
such as global payments imbalances and postcrisis surveillance issues ranging from financial 
regulation to macroprudential framework. This will provide trainees with an opportunity to explore 
implications of the regional surveillance mechanism. ADB staff and consultants will conduct the 
course. Given that around 40 people from more than 15 countries with diversified economic 
development  and  financial  market  maturity  are  participating  in  the  training  program,  some 
modules will be adjusted to factor in the subregional background so that discussions will be 
more focused and the training program will be more manageable and productive as a whole. 
 
13.  The  mid-level  officials  who  will  attend  this  program  will  be  selected  from  finance 
ministries and central banks of countries in the region. Participants are expected to have the 
following minimum qualifications: 
 
(i)  a bachelor's degree (or the equivalent) in economics, statistics, or finance from a 
recognized university, and preferably a postgraduate qualification in the same 
field; 
(ii)  at  least  5  years  of  relevant  professional  work  experience,  with  a  strong 
background in economic and statistical analysis; 
(iii)  knowledgeable in MS Excel and preferably Eviews, and 
(iv)  currently working or expected to work in a department undertaking surveillance 
work. 
 
14.  A case study involving a couple of countries where surveillance units were established 
in the aftermath of the 1997–98 Asian financial crisis would be a good resource for use in the 
course. It will provide participants with valuable lessons and implications for a good case study 
model that could be used to take an in-depth look at the effectiveness of surveillance units in the 
midst of the recent economic and financial turmoil. In this context, a case study or research on 
regional economic surveillance and macroeconomic policy formulation for selected countries in 
East Asia will be done, in addition to the course on REFM. This will be conducted by ADB staff 
and international consultants. The research outcome will be presented to course participants 
and disseminated to the public, as appropriate, so that the findings from these case studies can 
be adapted to the specific circumstances of selected economies in Asia. 
 
15.  The REFM workshops will expose trainees to economic and financial data systems; 
emerging data standards; EWS and macroeconomic models; methods of policy analysis and 
formulation; how to achieve financial stability; and implications of monetary, exchange rate, and 
fiscal policies. These activities will help develop the technical skills and practical experience 
needed to sustain and support full understanding and ownership of issues related to REFM. 
Although  participation  in  this  training  program  will  be  open  to  most  developing  member 
countries, some countries are expected to participate to a higher degree. Since the capacity to 
conduct economic and financial monitoring in South Asian countries lags far behind ASEAN+3 
countries, more mid-level officials from these countries will be encouraged  to participate in this TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $1,300,000,  of  which  the  equivalent  of 
$1,200,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund

5   
 
(TASF-IV for $1,000,000 and TASF–other sources for $200,000). The ASEAN Secretariat and 
governments  of  participating  developing  member  countries  will  provide  in-kind  counterpart 
support, including salaries of participating staff from government agencies for the duration of the 
training program, estimated at $100,000. The detailed cost breakdown and proposed financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The TA will be implemented in close 
collaboration with the ASEAN Secretariat, participating countries' finance ministries and central 
banks, ADB regional departments, and other regional institutions, if available. ADB may also 
collaborate with an international organization to help organize the workshops held outside 
Manila. Participants in the course will closely coordinate with OREI and host countries during 
the training. The TA will be carried out from January 2010 to the expected completion date of 
July 2011. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.8 
 
18.  All consultants will be hired as individual consultants and in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of 
reference  for  the  consultants  and  resource  persons  are  in  Appendix  3.  Three  national 
consultants will (i) coordinate the planning and implementation of the REFM course; (ii) facilitate 
logistical arrangements, including day-to-day assistance to the trainees; (iii) help with project 
administration;  and  (iv)  provide  research  assistance  if  needed.  About  6–9  international 
consultants will be hired to help deliver lectures on REFM. They should have solid experience in 
macroeconomics and financial programming, including experience in teaching these and related 
subjects to government officials. Two to three economists will be contracted to complete a case 
study on economic and financial surveillance and macroeconomic policy formulation. National 
consultants will be engaged for 28 person-months total and international consultants for 15 
person-months total. Ten to twelve resource people will be invited to speak on different special 
topics  or  current  issues  on  regional  cooperation  and  integration  as  well  as  statistics  and 
econometrics.  To  successfully  implement  this  TA,  a  team  of  OREI  staff  including  one 
professional staff member, one national officer, and one operations assistant, will consolidate 
consultants' individual outputs, and coordinate and administer individual consultant contracts.  
 
19.  For  this  course,  ADB  will  provide  round-trip  economy  airfare,  per  diem,  hotel 
accommodation, and miscellaneous travel expenses for the trainees, plus training material and 
logistics. Participation in all TA activities will be on a voluntary basis. During the training, the 
trainees' salaries will continue to be met by their respective governments. Trainees will not be 
employees of ADB.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis 
for  Technical  Training  and  Capacity  Building  for  Selected  Asian  Countries  on  Regional 
Economic  and  Financial  Monitoring,  and  hereby  reports  this  action  to  the  Board.

9  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance will provide the services of international consultants, national 
consultants,  and  resource  persons.  International  consultants  will  mainly  assist  in  
(i) delivering the training program for mid-level officials from Asian countries' finance ministries 
and central banks on regional economic and financial monitoring (REFM), and (ii) producing 
case  study  research  outputs  on  economic  and  financial surveillance,  and  economic  policy 
formulation. National consultants will facilitate the planning, design, revision, and delivery of 
training programs, including assistance in administration and logistics, as needed. Resource 
persons will mainly be engaged for short periods during the REFM training courses to deliver 
lectures  and  case  study  research  activities.  The  consultants  and  resource  persons  will  be 
selected and engaged in accordance with the ADB of the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). 
A.  Macroeconomists or Economists (8–12 international consultants, 15 person-months) 
2.  In  consultation  with  ADB  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration,  international 
consultants  will  be  engaged  to  facilitate  the  REFM  training  program.  They  will  have  solid 
experience in macroeconomics and finance, including teaching these and related subjects to 
government officials with various backgrounds in a short course or workshop. The consultants 
will prepare and present an REFM training module that is a component of the REFM training 
program. The training includes the following activities: review different macroeconomic and 
financial  accounts  (real  sector,  external  sector,  fiscal sector,  monetary  sector,  and  flow  of 
funds),  and  their  interrelationships;  present  and  analyze  a  case  study  to  illustrate  how 
projections are made and used; design a macroeconomic and financial program, and show how 
this is used as a tool in analyzing and formulating macroeconomic policies; and facilitate group 
workshops. 
3.  Two to three international consultants will be engaged to conduct a case study or 
prepare a research paper on economic and financial surveillance and macroeconomic policy 
formulation. 
 
B.   Research  Associate  and  Project  Coordinator  (1  national  consultant,  12  person-
months) 
4.  In consultation with ADB Office of Regional Economic Integration, the consultant will be 
in charge of the overall administration of the technical assistance, oversee the organization and 
conduct of the different courses and workshops, help the international consultants prepare and 
facilitate the different modules of the course, and provide research assistance if required.  
 
C.   Events Coordinator (2 national consultants, 16 person-months total) 
5.  The consultants will assist in facilitating and coordinating the REFM training courses, 
help liaise and coordinate with ADB staff and counterparts in other institutions when organizing 
REFM workshops, and organize workshops and video conferences including all logistics and 
administrative support, as needed.

10 
 
D.  Resource Persons (10–12 resource persons, 1.3 person-month total) 
 
6.  Ten to twelve resource persons will be engaged for short periods during each REFM 
training course to deliver lectures on various issues of regional cooperation and integration and 
surveillance. These include the following topical issues: (i) financial crises and financial stability 
assessment; (ii) special topics in macroeconomics, including trade, investment, and the global 
economy; (iii) vulnerability indicators and early warning systems; (iv) best practice approach on 
how to detect economic and financial vulnerabilities in developed countries; (v) econometrics; 
and (vi) postcrisis surveillance issues.
